Posts.Content: May 31, 2009 06:40PM nelia48 wrote: I finished my rads on April 15th, and I still feel very tired.  I burned to a crisp, but that is all healed up now.  The tired stuff hit me about the second week of rads.
Posts.Title: Getting Rads, feel lousy? robinri robinri

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2009 07:32AM nelia48 wrote: I drove myself to all my chemos, but my sister did go with me.  She had committed herself right from the start that she would go with me to all my appointments, etc., and hasn't failed me yet.  It was nice to have someone there to talk with, etc.  I was ok with driving there and home each time. Cora
Posts.Title: Can you drive yourself to chemo appointments? arnie SoCalLisa

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2009 06:50AM nelia48 wrote: Yes, it does sound like the diagnosis should be stage 3.  And I wish I had known at the time that I was automatically eligible for disability.  I could have gotten it 5 months earlier!
Posts.Title: Am I stage II or Stage III jeanjean_chang nelia48

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2009 06:57AM nelia48 wrote: I have to agree that I, too, wanted everything in the arsenal that my oncologist would throw at me.  I didn't want to pass up on anything.  As sick as I was during chemo, I had "separation issues" when it was over.  I was actually asking if there was such a thing as "booster chemos" that I could have just it case there were stray cells floating around!!!!!!  I am just dying with this awful radiation --- purple, full of blisters, skin weeping, and very painful --- but I just keep going back.  Being a 3b who let the tumor grow for 8 years before seeking help, I need everything I can get!
Posts.Title: Am I stage II or Stage III jeanjean_chang nelia48

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2009 03:42PM nelia48 wrote: Hi, Patty!  I don't think any of us "sucked it up" very well on that awful day we got the news!  So don't feel like you have to be the "suck it up" hero!!!!!  There is a special thread for gals with DCIS and you will find a ton of information there, too. You WILL get through all this -- I did, and if I can do it, anyone can!
Posts.Title: Kinda scared.... MamaLambNC margiejune

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2009 07:30PM nelia48 wrote: I agree that word of mouth is probably the best thing there is in chosing an oncologist, etc.  For me, I knew I was in for a hard, long journey, but my sister had the best oncologist and he had saved her life a few years before.  He had a few quirks in his personality, but I could live with that.  I just wanted someone who knew what he was doing.  So far, I haven't been disappointed.  I'm so sorry you had to join our group here, but glad you did as it will be so helpful for you!  I remember the days of getting all the scans, etc.  Scarey, I know!  But take each step as it comes and take deep breaths!  Hope it all goes well tomorrow! Cora
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed - what should we look for in a doctor? Snowflake70 LindaYO

Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2009 05:12PM nelia48 wrote: After he pulled out the drains, I never went back again to see the surgeon.  I was being followed by my oncologist, going through radiation by that time and seeing the radiologist, and seeing my primary care physician,  so I figured if there was anything wrong with the surgical site, they would send me back to the guy.  I couldn't think of any reason to add one more dr. to the list of who I had to see.
Posts.Title: How long do I continue with breast surgeon? jbau Erica

Posts.Content: May 1, 2009 06:31AM nelia48 wrote: I know many of you are saying that the creams, etc., are not working.  Don't stop using them (except when the dr. says it's an allergic reaction, etc!).  You have to remember that the burning is delayed with radiation, so today's cream is several days late for the burns you are seeing now.  I kept on using the stuff, no matter what, and in the end, everything healed up very fast.  Even after the last treatment, the burns got worse and worse for about 5 days, then stayed about the same for a few days, then all of a sudden started healing up.  The healing process was hard, as it seemed to crack open every time I bent or leaned or stood up!  Very irritating.  My last was April 15th, and right now I have only a penny sized area that is still scabbed.  The rest is all healed up and fading away.  You'll make it through, I promise!!!!!  I did!
Posts.Title: RADIATION FATIGUE - POLL bluejay1 Siciliana

Posts.Content: May 26, 2009 07:25AM nelia48 wrote: Linda, I don't work a night shift, but I could have during radiation since I couldn't sleep a wink anyways!!!!!  I was tired, but just couldn't sleep!
Posts.Title: RADIATION FATIGUE - POLL bluejay1 Siciliana

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2009 07:21AM nelia48 wrote: I think the fatigue hit me more at the end of it all -- more so than during the rads treatments.  I don't know if it was all just the emotional build up and then the let down, or if it is real fatigue or what.  But this last week (I finished last Wed), I've been a couch potato.  I tried yesterday to get up and vacuum, dust, etc., and I lasted about 15 minutes and that was it.  I got sweaty, breathless, my chest hurt, and I just caved in.  I do plan on trying to do something each day because I can't stand this laying around all day!  It's worse than anything!  Too much time to think about things!
Posts.Title: RADIATION FATIGUE - POLL bluejay1 Siciliana

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2009 08:50AM nelia48 wrote: I'm doing tx #27 today.  The fatigue thing was really sneaky for me.  I'd come home, go visit my sister for a while and had coffee with her, then come back, and woosh, I'd be snoring in the recliner.  Haven't felt like cooking in days, as my taste is off, too.  Then, at bedtime, I felt I couldn't keep my eyes open, but then couldn't fall asleep.  Even the tylenol PM doesn't help anymore.  So I'm not sure if it is rotten nights of sleep or the radiation. . .???
Posts.Title: RADIATION FATIGUE - POLL bluejay1 Siciliana

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2009 04:50PM nelia48 wrote: I, too, think it is different with different types of cancer, the size of the tumor, etc.  Mine was very large, so I had chemo even before surgery.  Mine was chemo, then surgery, then rads.  My sister had colon cancer, and hers was surgery, then chemo, then she had chemo along WITH radiation at the same time.  I know there are different chemos for breast cancer, too, and some are over a longer period of time.  Mine were 6 treatments, 3 weeks apart.  So it will depend on what your oncologist sets up for you.
Posts.Title: What comes first chemo or rads amlg1 nelia48

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2009 04:38PM nelia48 wrote: I had my last chemo on Dec 3, 08.  Then had surgery Jan 7, 09.  I can tell you gals this:  it did come back sometime in Febuary, but then I started radiation and lost it again for a while.  Not as bad or as long as with chemo. Some things are still on the "no" list as far as taste.  It's like, when you get nausaus or sick on something and just the smell makes you sick again.  For instance, I just can't drink coffee anymore.  Ice coffee is fine, but hot coffee just won't go down.  And I was a coffee addict!!!!! It's a slow thing!  And all of a sudden you realize that you are smelling and tasting things again.  I think the smell thing came first.
Posts.Title: When will taste return moonwolf moonwolf

Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2009 06:01PM nelia48 wrote: I know I met with my oncologist several times before I started treatment.  I did have to have chemo first, though, as my tumor was too large and they wanted to shrink it first before surgery.  I agree, and I think you should have a consult with the oncologist first.  He can give you answers to all the "why's" and explain things better to you.  I never thought of my surgeon as having anything to do with my cancer problem.  He was just there to cut it out and stitch me up!
Posts.Title: Am I choosing the right treatment? ssimmons66 achen2iron

Posts.Content: May 2, 2009 04:56PM nelia48 wrote: So glad to know that I'm not the only one who cannot sleep.  My Dr. gave me zanax and said it would help stop the racing thoughts at bedtime.  All I did was lie there thinking about when the racing thoughts would stop!!!!!  I toss and turn all night.  Between the hot sweats, the chills, etc., I just can't sleep either!  I'll have to try the milk thing and the benadryl.  Maybe a mix of the two!
Posts.Title: Sleep help please roxy42 Fire44fly

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2009 01:01PM nelia48 wrote: I had the chemo before surgery and did remarkably well, shrinking the tumor way down.  Oncologist was amazed at the results.  Had the mastectomy after that, but still had 5 out of 15 nodes positive.  Went through the radiation, and now doing ok.  But only 3 months out.  Had a PET scan a few weeks ago, and all was clean. I am confused with all of this.  Hope someone can help us out here.  When we have chemo first, then surgery, and the pathology report says like "5 out of 15 nodes positive"  ---- does this mean they are STILL live with cancer in them, or that they USED TO BE cancerous, just showing  up as having had the cancer.  I thought somewhere someone said that the chemo did it's work and killed the lymph nodes, too.  Am I wrong here?????
Posts.Title: The road less traveled carolesue Gayleebug

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2009 08:35AM nelia48 wrote: Hi, sutherndiva!  I know this all seems so impossible and threatening right now, but I went through it.  My tumor was very large -- had broken through the skin by the time I got treatment. I did the chemo first.  6 treatments, one every 3 weeks.  The tumor shrunk way down during that time until the dr. could hardly feel it.  Then I went for surgery, had the mastectomy, and then radiation.  I'm all done now -- 10 months later.  I really thought I couldn't do it, but I did.  The chemo first thing seems to becoming more of a way to do things, especially if the tumor is larger! If you have any questions at all, I'd be glad to walk you through what I went through and how it all was!  Hang in there, gal!
Posts.Title: Hope Seems Fleeting sutherndiva nene2059

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2009 04:33PM nelia48 wrote: I had a mastectomy on Jan 7th, and by the first of March, I was on that table getting radiation.  I hardly felt that my stitched had healed.  But they want to start as soon as possible after surgery to catch any remaining cells before they travel somewhere else!
Posts.Title: How soon after surgery? nanabolini carollynn79

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2009 09:22AM nelia48 wrote: I found a very small lump while showering back in the spring of 2001.  Yep ---- 2001!!!!  It was in a strange place --- lower part of my breast - by the bra line.  I had no insurance and no money to speak of, so just let it go until July of 2008.  By that time, it had grown extremely large, had broken through the skin, my arm was hurting, etc., and I was prepared to just die from this.  Someone told me about a free mammogram, and I went just to get them from bugging me further. When they saw the mammogram and how large it was, etc., etc., they told me of a federally funded program for women with little or no income who have breast and/or cervical cancer.  I was accepted into that program.  Staged at 3b.  Tumor had fully taken over the breast. A biopsy was done, CT, bone scan, etc., and was started on chemo treatments first as it was too large to remove first.  I responded very well to that.  Now, just finishing up radiation.   Last PET scan showed no spread. Too bad I didn't know about this program earlier! Cora
Posts.Title: How were you diagnosed? Symptoms/Signs, etc? greenacres nelia48

Posts.Content: nelia48 wrote: I had my initial consult with the radiologist today and he wants me to have hyperthermal treatments along with the radiation.  I have stage 3b, with the tumor invading through the skin with a big open lesion.  He said since it invaded the skin, I'm at a greater risk for return cancer and that the heating of the skin before radiation treatments gives better results.  Anyone else have this and what were the after effects????  I'm scared to death!  Cora Visit my blog at www.hiddenrichessecretplaces.b... Diagnosos: IDC - T4, N2, ER+, PR+, Grade 2, 5/15 lymph nodes, diagnosed 7/2008 Stage IIIb Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Hyperthermal Treatment????? nelia48 nelia48

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2009 08:38PM nelia48 wrote: seaofhope, I see so many of the ladies here have spoken their heart, and I, too, want to add to all of their words that  I am so sorry you had to join us here.  But glad that you found us, because this is the place to get allthe information, encouragement, and support you will need. I went to a dr. with my lump and when he saw it, just told me right then and there that he was 99.9% sure it was advanced cancer.  But I had let mine go for about 7 years and it had gotton so large, dimpled, and come through the skin already, so he could just look at it and know.  But I still had to go through all the steps of mammogram, biopsy, etc.  And each step seemed to take forever to get the results back. Take a deep breath, and please know that all of this is just one step at a time, one day at a time.  It IS doable, you will get through it, and you will come out the other end a stronger, more wonderful person!!!!!
Posts.Title: When do I cry? seaofhope one-L

Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2009 01:46PM nelia48 wrote: seaofhope, how nice of this gal to see your fears and stay with you like that!  There will be others along the way that just seem to have the ability to get you through.  I call them my angels!!!!  It seems that through each phase of this journey, they have been there just at the right time! Sounds like you are in good hands and I know you will get through this!  Keep us updated on what's next, etc.
Posts.Title: When do I cry? seaofhope one-L

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2009 08:27PM nelia48 wrote: Angie, I just signed on tonight, and yours was the first message I read!  What an upbeat, wonderful message to find!  Isn't it great to know you are DONE???!!!!!  I, too, finished a little while ago.  Never thought I could do it.  Never thought I'd even live to see this day.  But God had different plans, saw me through it all, and here I am!  I agree, I think everyone just starting out on this journey needs to hear from us at the end of the path.  I, too, am here for anyone who needs a shoulder, a hand to hold, etc.  Thanks, Angie, for a wonderful note!
Posts.Title: I am done angie27 Maire67

Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2009 01:48AM nelia48 wrote: I want to welcome both of you here, but also sorry that you had to join this club.  I know how hard this must be for both of you, as the beginning seems to be the hardest, doesn't it?  I had to have chemo first to shrink the tumor.  I was all prepared for surgery, thinking that ALWAYS comes first, but it doesn't anymore.  Chemo was hard, I did lose my hair, but it came back.  It did it's job and shrunk the tumor to nothing.  I'm like you, Gma, I didn't remember anything that was told to me, and had to ask again.  Nor did I question my oncologist's decisions on the treatment plan.  I figured he had treated hundreds beforeme and knew the best plan for me.  I thought I couldn't do chemo --- but I did it!  I thought I couldn't do the surgery, but I got through that.   I thought radiation was terrible, but that's all behind me and I got through that.  It all took about 10 months from the day of diagnosis to the end of it all.  And all of that was NOT horrible!  We tend to remember the horrible days! Read everything you can here on this site.  The information is wonderful and all the ladies will help you through this!  Ask all your questions, vent your feelings, etc. You will make it through!  I promise!
Posts.Title: Terrified, angry, depressed Twinmom77 cancersister

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2009 05:07PM nelia48 wrote: I found my lump myself, it was hard, not moveable.  Pea sized.  Didn't go for mammogram or treatment for about 7 years afterwards, so it was VERY large by that time. No breast cancer in my family, but lots of other types of cancers.
Posts.Title: WHAT did YOUR lump FEEL like? gscott MomOfTeenGirl01

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2009 04:54PM nelia48 wrote: I'm on tx #27 today, and I must say, my ribs are killing me.  Have been almost from the beginning.  I worry a little, being it is the left side, and from what I have read, there can be heart damage as well as lung and rib damage.  Also, right now the scar area is open, oozing, and feels like there is a hot knife in it.  Hoping to see the dr. today to get something for the pain!  And the tightness?  yes, I get that, too.   Feels like someone pulling an ace bandage really tight across my chest.
Posts.Title: Soreness and Pain after Radiation Minnegirl1 Shirlann

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2009 07:44PM nelia48 wrote: Ann, I had the same chemo as you, and had a lot of weird side effects!!!!  My pee burned so bad and it burned holes in my panties.  My teeth ached so bad I thought I would die.  My skin peeled off the bottoms of my feet -- I couldn't walk for several days it was so bad!  My heart pounded and raced til I thought it was going to jump out of my chest.  I felt like I had a burning brick in my gut and could eat nothing but Cream of Wheat cereal.    Horrible!!!!!   Cora
Posts.Title: What's your wierdest side effect ann-idiot ann-idiot

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2009 04:39PM nelia48 wrote: I agree with Bugs!  I want this family doctor!!!! Cora
Posts.Title: patient-doctor relationship: your thoughts and experiences paige-allyson KerryMac

Posts.Content: May 30, 2009 07:26PM nelia48 wrote: I had the same question!  After I had the drains pulled out and the stitches removed, I never went back as I had no trouble.  I moved on to my radiation treatments, went through that, and have seen my oncologist a few times.  I can't for the life of me think of a reason why I would see my surgeon again.  I could understand if I had an infection in my stitches or something like that, but I didn't so didn't even go for that 1 month follow up.  Should I have gone?
Posts.Title: Why continue seeing surgeon after tx has ended crazy4carrots JROGBURN

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2009 10:24PM nelia48 wrote: Hi, Little Flower!  I know how you are feeling, too!  Every night, I lay in bed and think of all the what if's, wonder about the future, think of the pains I'm feeling, etc.  I've had rib pain ever since radiation and it's not letting up any.  But I did have a PET scan a few weeks ago, and everything was clean.  So yes, I also know about the sigh of relief for a while.  It's so hard, isn't it?  always living with this awful wondering.  I had my oncologist visit today, and I went away a little worried, too.  Even though there's nothing to worry about now, he did tell me that  there was a very good chance that it would come back and that I could NOT get my port taken out!  Reality check, for sure! Get the bone scan.  Tell your onc all about what's bothering you.  NOT getting the scan doesn't change what is.  Better to know and get it treated early!  Let us know what happens, and I'll be thinking of you til then!
Posts.Title: hip pain LittleFlower NancyD

Posts.Content: May 31, 2009 11:55AM nelia48 wrote: I used "My Girls Radiation Cream" --- bought it from their website on the internet.  It's all natural and wonderful.  I also used the recommended Aquaphor --- but it's very greasy.  Aloe Vera is a good natural thing to use.  Calendula helps a lot.  I think there are some threads here that  discuss the different products.  That's where I found the Radiation Cream and I loved it!
Posts.Title: Creams/lotions for rads Leah_S desdemona222b

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2009 01:31PM nelia48 wrote: I'm so surprised at how everyone's treated differently and that the care is so different for each person.  The first person I saw was the oncologist and it was him that set everything up for me ----- chemo, surgery, radiation, etc.  I always go back to him with everything, and he tells me who I should see, etc.  He is the one that prescribed the Arimidex hormone treatment for me.  And he's the one who sets up the scans and reads them.  I barely ever saw the radiology oncologist, and I only saw the surgeon once after the drains were pulled out.  I guess it's different for everyone.
Posts.Title: oncologist? ma27 Seabee

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2009 01:14PM nelia48 wrote: I also started Arimidex right after surgery in January and continued taking it all throughout my radiation in March and April.  No problems here either!
Posts.Title: Taking tomaxifen while going through radiation bqswnnhn09 1Cathi

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2009 10:03AM nelia48 wrote: Gees, Maeve!  That is just the greatest!  More doctors should have such compassionate and caring hearts like that!  Cora
Posts.Title: patient-doctor relationship: your thoughts and experiences paige-allyson KerryMac

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2009 09:14AM nelia48 wrote: I've really enjoyed reading everyone's experiences with their oncologists!  Maybe "enjoyed" is not the right word here!!!!  But anyways. . . . I just had a visit with my oncologist and it was a hard one for me.  Maybe because I'm almost through with treatment and I'm experiencing "separation issues" with him.  All through treatment, I couldn't wait to be over with it all, but now, I'm feeling some low key anxiety about NOT being treated anymore.  Yesterday was a strange visit, as he was just so happy and jolly.  And when he looked at the mastectomy sight, he was just elated and overjoyed with how well it had closed and healed up, as he never really expected it to close like that. (My tumor was so large that it had come through the skin.)  I seemed to burst his celebration balloons when I asked about my future and what to look for as signs of my cancer returning.  He has never believed in all the stats and figures and percentages either.  He kind of said the "50/50 -- it will either return or it won't" thing to me, too.  I just wish there was something to DO to keep it from coming back besides anxiously wait and see! Cora http://www.hiddenrichessecretplaces.blogspot.com/
Posts.Title: patient-doctor relationship: your thoughts and experiences paige-allyson KerryMac

Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2009 05:23PM nelia48 wrote: This was great to read here, but it left me wondering whether to wait to Jan 8th, when I have my next onc visit, or if I should call.  For a month now, I have been freezing cold.  Up til now, for about a year, I've been boiling hot with the Arimidex, etc.  Slept with ice packs, fans -- you know how it goes.  I'm in florida, and everyone has their air conditioning going.  But here I am, socks, slippers, three sweatshirts, robes, three quilts on my bed and I can't get warm ---- ever.  Is this something worth mentioning????  Sometimes I feel like a paranoid fanatic who reads cancer into every chill bump, but would hate to let it go too long if it is a sign of something.  Chills is NOT listed on the bottle of Arimidex as a side affect.
Posts.Title: Signs of Mets Pure barbe1958

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2009 02:03AM nelia48 wrote: I ordered the My Girls Radiation Cream off their website.  I love it and still use it.  I had my last radiation on April 15th and do you know that the area is still warm to the touch?  So I thought since there is still heat in it, I would continue to use the cream.  Love it!
Posts.Title: Severe radiation burns to the breast RCindy

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2009 02:04AM nelia48 wrote: Meridith, I also used the saline to clean mine.  I used a sterile spray bottle and sprayed it on the burned area.  Didn't have to touch it that way.
Posts.Title: Severe radiation burns to the breast RCindy

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2009 06:30PM nelia48 wrote: Yes, I wore my own clothing as we didn't wear hospital gowns, etc.  Our cancer center had a lot of afgans that people had hand made and donated and I always felt wrapped in love when I needed one.  Such a lovely thing to do! People also donated wigs, chemo hats, etc.  As soon as I'm sure I'm done with all this, I'll donate mine.
Posts.Title: What do you pack for Chemo? BShoemaker Moderators

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2009 05:49PM nelia48 wrote: I, too, had a very large tumor and lymph node involvement!  I did the taxotere and cytoxin before surgery, but did the opposite from you ---- I was given triple doses --- six of them.   It was horrible and thought I would just die during it all.  But it worked and shrunk everything to almost nothing.  If you are getting more chemo afterwards, it should knock it out.  As the others have said, your team will come up with the best plan for you.  There is hope, so get out the gloves and fight! Cora
Posts.Title: Path report need suppor- Prognosis stats mentioned in post thisisme nelia48

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2009 07:20AM nelia48 wrote: I know I feel terribly tired and I'm on my 6th treatment.  But I do think it is still a "hangover" from chemo, surgery, etc.  I'm just tired of the whole thing.  I don't know why, but the radiation thing just seems to be throwing me over the edge.  It doesn't hurt, etc.  But this every day thing is already getting to me.  This morning I'm already thinking of quitting!!!
Posts.Title: Is something wrong with me? 4thefather kirbyloo

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2009 10:51AM nelia48 wrote: Our chemo room was so cold, but they did have afgans available - 1 for each chair.  They also had pillows and always had a fresh, clean pillowcase on them.  I had a port, so I wore a loose blouse, making the port site readily available.  I also wore elastic waist pants because I had to pee a LOT!!!!  In fact, I learned after the first session to wear a pad in my pants!!!!  And bring some extras.  I barely made it to the ladies room. I was always hungry, and some people brought stuff from fast food places and the smells made me want to jump up and grab their food.  So be prepared for the hungries.  I always brought lots of water, grapes, some cookes, hard candies, a book (but I never read them), and anything else I was interested in that day.  Maybe a magazine or something.  It was nice if people were chatty -- it passed the time better.  Sometimes it was dead silent for some reason and no one wanted to talk.
Posts.Title: What do you pack for Chemo? BShoemaker Moderators

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2009 09:48AM nelia48 wrote: I've heard that a lot of people don't like my oncologist, but since my sister had him a few years before and saved her life, I was already prepared for his blunt, upfront honesty, etc.  He tells it like it is, trys to make you feel stronger than you think you are, that you can get through it, etc.  I thought I would be so glad to not have to see him so often, but now that the appointments are getting farther and farther apart, I think I'm having separation anxiety issues!!!!!!  I'm almost done with treatment, and I keep feeling that maybe there is something else I should be getting or should be doing just in case ---- like maybe "booster chemos" if there were such a thing.  I remember thinking that I would be so happy when it was all overwith, and I am, but there is something about being on my own that scares me!  That tells me I had way more trust in my oncologist than I thought I did! Cora
Posts.Title: patient-doctor relationship: your thoughts and experiences paige-allyson KerryMac

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2009 09:35AM nelia48 wrote: I find it very strange that they say sugar does not feed cancer, but when you get a PET scan, they inject you with radioactive glucose stuff.  They have you fast before hand so that the cancer cells are "hungry" and grab onto the sugar in the injection!!!!!  What conclusion would you come to from that????  But I'm like the rest of you. . . . I till put sugar in my tea in the morning.  I can't think that all the crap in diet drinks is better for you than plain old sugar.  And I wouldn't think twice about having that piece of chocolate cake either!
Posts.Title: BC - Should you avoid dairy and sugar??? np312 debisongbird

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2009 06:46PM nelia48 wrote: Hi, Cook1.  I just finished my radiation treatments on the 15th.  Yes, they did take pictures a few times.  And they took LOTS of x=rays during the first half of the treatments just to make sure I was lined up right, etc.  I had the tatoos, my face photo was on my chart, etc.  Idaho is right -- I've lost all my dignity, bare my chest to anyone who wants to see it, and hardly tie my gown on in the dressing room and go flapping in the breeze! I was one who had a hard time with the radiation.  I have such bad burns, and I'm still dealing with them 2 weeks after the last treatment.  I'm tired all the time, my taste is a little off, my ribs are killing me, and I have these stabbing pains through my chest.  Other than that, I'm fine!!!!!(?????) I started my radiation in March, so I've been following the march rads group.  You might want to join in the April group so you can keep up on who is reacting to what, etc.  These groups are such a big help --- supportive, informative, compassionate, and helpful!
Posts.Title: Just started Radiation cook1 Neblin

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2009 02:26AM nelia48 wrote: I also had the severe burns.  It was just terrible and I felt like a crispy critter for weeks afterwards. I used "My Girls Radiation Cream" along with the silver sulphadia. . . .???  stuff, also the Aquaphor, etc.  Remember, radiation burns are slow to show up and are behind a few days, so it gets worse before it gets better.  I found I could not put the cream on with my fingers and spread it around.  I was just pulling off more and more skin.  So, I took bandages, smeared the cream onto that, then laid the bandages on the burned areas.  I can't really say if any of it helped, but it did get better quite quickly after radiation stopped.  Just watch for infection.  You don't want that!
Posts.Title: Severe radiation burns to the breast RCindy

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2009 10:21AM nelia48 wrote: Irishred, I went to my county health dept here in Florida and got onto the same program for women with breast and/or cervical cancer.    It was a life saver for me, and I know you, too. Is there a reason why you wouldn't do chemo?  I went through it last fall.  My oncologist said I didn't have a chance at all if I did not do the chemo.  I never questioned it.
Posts.Title: Refuse To Do Surgery makingway nelia48

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2009 02:23PM nelia48 wrote: Hi, Nannajean!  So sorry to hear about your diagnosis and that you find yourself in this place!  But this IS by far, the best place for help, encouragement, and the information you need. I was diagnosed a year ago with  stage 3b, a HUGE tumor, and lymph node involvement.  I had let it go a very long time (7 years), and it was breaking through the skin.  Didn't need a biopsy for lymph node involvement ---- they could feel it!  After biopsy of the tumor, I had to do the chemo first to shrink the tumor.  Then surgery and then radiation.  Surgery showed 5 out of 15 nodes positive.  I'm telling you all this because I just had a PET scan last week, and it came out clean with no spread anywhere.  So yes, the lymph nodes did their job and caught it and kept it from spreading. Before starting chemo, etc., I had a chest xray, bone scan, and an MRI.  They saw no spread anywhere at that time either.  So don't panic!  Take a deep breath!  I know your thoughts are racing, thinking the worst, etc., etc.  But this is all doable.  I'm 61 years old, did the chemo, lost my hair, went through surgery and radiation, and here I am, getting on with life.  If you have any questions whatsoever, you can send me a private message and ask away.  I'd be glad to help in any way I can!
Posts.Title: new diagnoses nannajean ritajean

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2009 08:21PM nelia48 wrote: I loved this thread!!!!!  Brought back LOTS of memories! I didn't know I would be so sick to my stomach from the pain pills they gave me in the hospital! I didn't know I'd be so constipated!!!!! I didn't know I wouldn't be able to pick things up off the floor. I didn't know that I couldn't wipe myself with my other arm!  Had always done it with the left!  My right didn't work! I didn't know getting up off the toilet would be a major issue!
Posts.Title: Things that surprised me after mastectomy Lursa5 Ariom

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2009 02:01PM nelia48 wrote: You know, maybe I'm the oddball here, but it has only been recently that I have even thought about my prognosis and that the cancer might come back.  Maybe I was just so focussed on treatment, chemo, surgery, radiation, etc., and getting through it all that my thought process just couldn't wrap around tomorrow.  Now that I'm almost through with it all, I'm started to look more at the percentages, etc.  For a while, I couldn't wait for all of this crap to be done with. . . . now, I wish there was something more that I could do to keep it from coming back. .. . like "booster chemos" or something. I'm with you, Kim.  I don't want to talk about the percentages.  None of us will never know which side of the percentages we are on anyways.  It only causes ulcers and nervous breakdowns! Cora
Posts.Title: Path report need suppor- Prognosis stats mentioned in post thisisme nelia48

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2009 11:05AM nelia48 wrote: I had such bad indigestion that there wasn't much I could eat, to say nothing of the taste of things being just terrible. It did help, though, when I started taking a prilocec every day. The Carnation Instant Breakfast drinks are a great nutrion boost and tasted good to me.  I also ate a LOT of Cream of Wheat cereal made with milk instead of water, and chicken noodle soup.  The little pudding cups were life savors.  Sherbet was great for a while, but later on seemed to take on a bitter taste. I came to this conclusion:  Any foods that had mixed flavors were terrible or I could not taste them at all.  For instance, spagetti sauce was one that was way off.  Too many mixed things in there.  And soups with lots of veggies and tastes were no good.  The more simple the food was, the better it was.  Sometimes, just a piece of toast and a scrambled egg were just fine.  Forget any of the breakfast meats, like sausage, bacon, etc.  No good.  And it all changed from one chemo treatment to the next.  Seemed like what I ate at the beginning, I couldn't eat at the end.  You just have to try stuff.  When all else fails, drink an Ensure!
Posts.Title: Food Suggestions - Please mln8428 nelia48

Posts.Content: May 29, 2009 07:50PM nelia48 wrote: I had a mastectomy of left breast in Jan. 09.  I went in at 6:00 am, and was out the next day at noon.  Everything went fine, but I got really sick to my stomach after they gave me the pain pill the next morning.  Wish I hadn't taken it as I wasn't really in pain.  The drains were a nuisance more than anything.  No pain there.  had to empty them a couple times a day and keep track of how much came out each time.  When it was almost nothing, went back and he pulled them out.  I was so anxious, but they were out before I knew it and felt nothing. I had 5 out of 15 nodes positive, and one of the nodes had a problem and was all wrapped around one of the shoulder nerves and he couldn't get it loose, so had to cut the nerve.  He was afraid I would have problems with the shoulder and arm, but it ended up that I did not and it's ok.  Everything healed up just fine, and before I knew it, I was worrying about radiation and surgery was left in the dust. The only major problem I had that no one told me about was constipation!!!!!!  If you take pain meds, be SURE to take something to prevent that!  I can't stress that enough!
Posts.Title: What to expect with a Mastectomy? floridian tnmtnmomma

Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2009 03:49PM nelia48 wrote: My ribs still hurt and I have a hard time sleeping on that side.  On the other side, I have that port thiingy, so I'm stuck laying on my back staring at the ceiling.  LeggyJ, I hate those answers with the shrug of the shoulders, etc.  I've gotten that a few times.  Somehow, I want that guy to know everything and have an answer for me about everything I ask!
Posts.Title: Ribcage pain after rads -Months later? Krissy37 MBCR

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2009 06:32PM nelia48 wrote: I finished rads in April, and here I'm still having trouble swallowing.  In fact, there are times that I feel I'm being strangled and can't breathe.  There are certain things I can't swallow ---- like cooked spinach.  It won't go down.  Gets stuck in my throat.  Sorry to say, it hasn't gotten better since rads.  I did have problems with esophogitis, but that went away a few weeks after rads were done.  Hope it gets better for you!
Posts.Title: Difficulty swallowing, a radiation side efffect? nanabolini yoga_girl

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2009 06:06PM nelia48 wrote: I went for a mammogram first, then to the surgeon.  The surgeon looked at the mammogram, and wrote a referral to the oncologist. The surgeon also made the arrangements for the biopsy, as nothing could be done without that being done first to see what KIND of cancer we were dealing with.  The oncologist also looked at the mammograms, waited for the biopsy results, then told me that chemo had to be first to shrink the tumor, then surgery, etc.   Somewhere, someone will tell you what the order of events are.  Usually, you will need the referral to the oncologist (or Cancer Center).  Sounds like you already had the biopsy???? as you know the type of cancer you have.  I know how it is with the weekends and the waiting part.  Very hard.  But like Linda said, take deep breaths and know that what is, is!  No use making up scenerios in your mind that will never come true!  Just try to wait patiently.  Take a pen and notebook with you to write stuff down because it will be thrown at you and by the time you get out of the office, you won't remember anything correctly! Let us know how it goes!
Posts.Title: What do I do first Surgery/Oncology?? julielb julielb

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2009 04:24PM nelia48 wrote: I agree with you, Kathy and Angel!  All I ever hear is "not from rads" or "not from chemo" or whatever.  Or. . . just the "hmmmm!!!!" with no explanation or help.  Sometimes I get the feeling that these dr.s think I'm the biggest whiner in the place.  All I'd really like to hear is that, yes, this goes with the territory, we're sorry, but it should pass as time goes on, or something like that.  That would ease my mind a lot!
Posts.Title: Muscle/joint pain after radiation? kat06365 Larai

Posts.Content: May 1, 2009 09:48AM nelia48 wrote: I also thought about the big, heavy door that goes into the radiation room, and the fact that the gals leave the room every time they zap us.  Must be a reason for that.  If they feel it affects THEM, it must affect us all over, too!  I'm noticing that I'm waking up at night with terrible hip pain.  Makes me terrified that it has spread!!!!
Posts.Title: Muscle/joint pain after radiation? kat06365 Larai

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2009 04:18PM nelia48 wrote: I only just finished my rad treatments on April 15th, so I'm no judge as to what is down the line for me.  I burned badly with horrible sores, had the stabbing pains in my chest, and my underarm swelled and hurt a lot.  Most of all the symptoms have subsided, but I'm just soooo tired, and have no strength at all.  When I try to do anything, I feel like my muscles have never been used before.    I thought things were bad during chemo, but it seems I just have no strength at all right now.  I feel like a real lump on the couch.  I was hoping this would go away soon and that I could get on with my life.  I feel so lazy!
Posts.Title: Muscle/joint pain after radiation? kat06365 Larai
